questions.text: Which of the following causes the rise in ESR during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fibrinogen

Explanation:

Fibrinogen is an acute-phase reactant, which means its levels increase in response to inflammation. During pregnancy, hormonal changes lead to increased levels of fibrinogen, resulting in an elevated ESR. This increase in fibrinogen is a normal physiological response and helps prepare the body for potential bleeding during childbirth.

  • During pregnancy, an increase in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a common finding.
  • ESR is a non-specific indicator of inflammation and reflects the rate at which red blood cells settle in a vertical tube over a specific time period.
  • It is influenced by several factors, including changes in blood composition and hormonal fluctuations during pregnancy.

 

While albumin (Option A) is an important plasma protein involved in maintaining oncotic pressure and transporting various substances, changes in its levels during pregnancy don't have a major impact on ESR.

Platelets (Option B) are essential for blood clotting, but they do not significantly affect ESR. Their count may change during pregnancy, but they don't cause a rise in ESR.

Anti-thrombin antibodies (Option D) affect the anticoagulant function of anti-thrombin III but are not associated with increased ESR during pregnancy. The rise in ESR is primarily linked to increased acute-phase proteins like fibrinogen.

questions.text: The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Echocardiography for cardiac disease

 

Explanation:
Except for echocardiography for cardiac disease, all other tests (urine analysis for bacteriuria, blood sugar levels for GDM, and VDRL for syphilis) are cost-effective investigations routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers.

 

Echocardiography is an expensive investigation not routinely recommended for all pregnant women but is indicated in specific conditions such as:

  • Abnormal genetic screening results (e.g., increased nuchal translucency >3 mm), requiring detailed ultrasound and fetal echocardiography.
  • Gestational diabetes mellitus, for early detection of fetal anomalies, typically performed at 20-22 weeks.
  • Maternal heart disease (e.g., congenital heart disease, Marfan's syndrome), to assess structural abnormalities or valve anatomy.

 

Routine Investigations During Pregnancy:

 

Trimester

Investigations

First Trimester
  • Hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Blood grouping and Rh typing
  • Blood glucose testing
  • VDRL testing
  • Midstream urine analysis (protein, sugar, nitrites)
  • Serology for rubella, hepatitis B, and HIV
  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (optional)
  • Ultrasound (Dating Scan): Confirms gestational age, fetal viability, and number of fetuses
  • Pap smear (if not done within the last year)

Second Trimester
  • Ultrasound (Anomaly Scan, 18–20 weeks): Assesses fetal anatomy, structural abnormalities, amniotic fluid index, and placental location
  • Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT, 24–28 weeks)
  • Repeat urine analysis
  • Quadruple marker screening (optional)
  • Antibody screening (for Rh-negative mothers)
  • Ultrasound (Fetal Echocardiography, if indicated): Detailed evaluation of fetal heart for congenital anomalies

Third Trimester
  • Repeat hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Repeat serology for syphilis, HIV, and hepatitis B
  • Vaginal and rectal swab for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) testing (35–37 weeks)
  • Ultrasound (Growth Scan): Monitors fetal growth, amniotic fluid levels, and placental function
  • Non-stress test (NST) or biophysical profile (BPP, if indicated)
  • Coagulation profile (if indicated)
  • Ultrasound (Doppler Scan, if indicated): Evaluates placental and fetal blood flow in conditions like IUGR or preeclampsia

questions.text: The following are correct regarding the normal placenta, except:

choices.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g
Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

 

Explanation:

  • Extraplacental membranes refer to the amnion and chorion, which are normal components
  • A 2-vessel umbilical cord (1 artery and 1 vein) is considered abnormal and is associated with conditions like fetal anomalies or growth restriction. The normal umbilical cord contains 3 vessels: 2 arteries and 1 vein.

General Characteristics of the Placenta

The placenta is a crucial organ in pregnancy, facilitating nutrient, gas, and waste exchange between the mother and fetus.

Shape and Size

  • Shape: Discoid, typically round to oval in shape.
  • Diameter: At term, the placenta measures approximately 22 cm in diameter. (Option B ruled out)
  • Thickness: The central thickness of the placenta at term is around 2.5 cm. (Option D ruled out)
  • Weight: The placenta weighs about 470 g at term. (Option A ruled out)

Structure

1. Chorionic Plate:

  • Found on the fetal surface.
  • Lined by the amniotic membrane.
  • The umbilical cord attaches to this surface.

2. Basal Plate:

  • Located on the maternal surface.
  • Faces the uterine wall.
  • Divided into segments called cotyledons, which are functional units of the placenta.

3. Extraplacental Membranes:

Includes the amnion and chorion, which protect and enclose the fetus.

4. Umbilical Cord:

  • Normally, it consists of three vessels: two arteries and one vein.
  • A two-vessel cord is abnormal and may indicate congenital anomalies or placental insufficiency.

Physiological Features

  • Deciduate: The placenta, along with the fetal membranes, is shed during delivery.
  • Hemochorial: Maternal blood directly contacts fetal trophoblast cells to enable efficient substance exchange.

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation (POG) calculation:

choices.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment
Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
In an IVF pregnancy, the day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG
Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

Explanation:

The period of gestation (POG) is typically calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.

Naegele’s Rule

 

Naegele's Rule is a standard method used to calculate the Estimated Date of Delivery (EDD) for a pregnant woman based on her Last Menstrual Period (LMP). It assumes a typical pregnancy duration of 280 days (40 weeks) from the first day of the LMP.

 

Steps to Calculate EDD Using Naegele's Rule:

  • Identify the first day of the Last Menstrual Period (LMP).
  • Add 9 months to this date or Subtract 3 months.
  • Add 7 days to the result.

 

This calculation works well for women with regular menstrual cycles of 28 days. Adjustments may be needed for women with irregular cycles.

 

Example:

If the LMP is March 10, 2024:

  • Add 9 months: December 10, 2024.
  • Add 7 days: December 17, 2024.

The EDD is December 17, 2024.

 

Options A, C and D are true.

 

Option A: Ultrasound in the first trimester, especially measuring the crown-rump length (CRL), is one of the best and most accurate methods for determining gestational age during early pregnancy, typically between 7 to 12 weeks.

 

Option C: In IVF pregnancies, the day of embryo transfer or fertilization is crucial for calculating the period of gestation (POG), as the exact date of conception is known.

 

Option D: Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most reliable and accurate measurement of gestational age in the first trimester, especially between 7 to 12 weeks, as it directly reflects the fetus's size during early.

questions.text: During the USG examination of a woman at 28 weeks of gestation, you observe her amniotic fluid index to be 12.8 cm. At what stage does this measurement typically reach its highest value in a healthy pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 32 weeks of gestation

Explanation:

  • In a healthy pregnancy, the amniotic fluid index (AFI) typically reaches its highest value around 32 to 34 weeks of gestation.
  • After this period, the amniotic fluid volume might start to gradually decrease as the pregnancy progresses toward full term.
  • AFI is an important measurement during ultrasound examinations, as it helps assess the amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.

questions.text: Cardiac output reverts to pre-pregnancy levels by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 10 days postpartum

Explanation:

  • Cardiac output increases during pregnancy to meet the increased demands of the growing fetus and maternal physiological changes.
  • After delivery, it takes some time for cardiac output to return back to pre-pregnant levels.
  • The timeframe for cardiac output to return to pre-pregnant levels varies among individuals but generally occurs within 10 days postpartum.
  • Several factors influence the age at which cardiac output normalizes, including the individual's overall health, fitness level, and any complications experienced during pregnancy or childbirth.

questions.text: What dose of folic acid is recommended for a woman who wants to become pregnant but has a history of pregnancy complicated with a neural tube defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4 mg/day

Explanation:

  • For women who have a history of a pregnancy complicated by a neural tube defect (NTD), the recommended dose of folic acid is higher than the standard prenatal recommendation. The standard daily recommendation for folic acid in pregnancy is 400 micrograms (mcg) per day.
  • However, in cases where there is a history of a previous pregnancy affected by NTD, the recommended dose of folic acid is typically higher, usually around 4,000 micrograms (4 milligrams) per day.
  • This higher dosage is prescribed to help reduce the risk of recurrence of NTDs in future pregnancies.

 

400 mcg/day (Option A): This is the standard recommended dose of folic acid for most women of childbearing age who are planning a pregnancy. However, for women with a history of an NTD-affected pregnancy, a higher dose is recommended to provide additional protection.

1 mg/day (Option B) & 2 mg/day (Option C): While this is a higher dose compared to the standard recommendation, it is still lower than the recommended dose for women with a history of an NTD-affected pregnancy. The specific recommendation in this case is a higher dose of 4 mg/day.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Inhibin B

 

Explanation: Inhibin B is not a component of the quadruple screening test.

 

Quadruple Marker

Down’s Syndrome

Edward’s Syndrome

Patau’s Syndrome

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (Option C)

↓

↓

↓

Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) (Option A)

↑

↓

↓

Unconjugated Estriol (uE3) (Option B)

↓

↓

↓

Inhibin A

↑

-

↑

Note: Inhibin A is not calculated for Edward’s Syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal checkup in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) G2P1

Explanation: The correct obstetric score is G2P1, as she is in her second pregnancy (G2), and her previous twin delivery counts as one parity (P1), regardless of the number of babies born.

The obstetric score includes:

Gravida

Denotes a pregnant state, both present and past, irrespective of the period of gestation

Parity

Denotes a state of previous pregnancy beyond the period of viability(28 weeks)

Abortion

Number of pregnancies lost before 24 weeks

Living

Number of living children

Note: Twin pregnancy counts as one for both gravida and parity.

G2P2 (Option A): This implies two pregnancies with two full-term deliveries, but her previous twin delivery counts as one parity (P1), and this is her second pregnancy (G2).

G3P2 (Option B): This suggests three pregnancies, which is not supported as she has only had two.

G3P1 (Option D): This indicates three pregnancies, but the scenario confirms only two

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient?

LMP- Last Menstrual Period

USG- Ultrasonography
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Crown-rump length by USG

Explanation: Ultrasound measurement of the crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate method to assess gestational age in early pregnancy.

Gestational Age Determination:

  • Based on the woman's Last Menstrual Period (LMP) and ultrasound measurements of the embryo or fetus.
  • Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the LMP, usually in weeks.
  • If LMP is uncertain or there is a discrepancy between LMP and ultrasound, ultrasound measurements determine the Estimated Due Date (EDD).

Ultrasound parameters for estimation of the gestational age:

  • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Most accurate before 14 weeks gestation. Accuracy is within 5-7 days.
  • After 14 weeks gestation: Additional measurements like biparietal diameter (BPD), head circumference (HC), abdominal circumference (AC), and femur length (FL) are used for gestational age and fetal weight estimation.

Gestational Age

Parameter

Threshold Value to Redate

<9 weeks

CRL

>5 days

9 to <14 weeks

CRL

>7 days

14 to <16 weeks

BPD, HC, AC, FL

>7 days

16 to <22 weeks

BPD, HC, AC, FL

>10 days

22 to <28 weeks

BPD, HC, AC, FL

>14 days

≥ 28 weeks

BPD, HC, AC, FL

>21 days

Adding 280 days to the LMP (Option B): This method assumes a pregnancy lasts 280 days (40 weeks) from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP). However, it may not be accurate for women with irregular cycles, as variations in cycle length and ovulation timing can affect gestational age calculation.

Fundus examination (Option C): This method estimates gestational age by palpating the top of the uterus to assess the height of the uterine fundus above the pubic symphysis. It is less accurate than ultrasound and can be influenced by factors like maternal weight and fetal position.

Adding 256 days to the LMP (Option D): Similar to Option B, this method assumes a fixed duration of pregnancy but with a shorter duration of 256 days. However, it is not a commonly used or recommended method for estimating gestational age.

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 8

 

Explanation:
The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to achieve a positive pregnancy outcome.

 

 

WHO Recommendations

Indian Recommendations (National Guidelines)

under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)

Minimum Visits

8 visits

4 visits

 

WHO Antenatal Care (ANC) Recommendations (2016 Update)

 

Visit No.

Timing

Visit 1

Up to 12 weeks

Visit 2

At 20 weeks

Visit 3

At 26 weeks

Visit 4

At 30 weeks

Visit 5

At 34 weeks

Visit 6

At 36 weeks

Visit 7

At 38 weeks

Visit 8

At 40 weeks

 

Indian Antenatal Care (ANC) Recommendations

 

Visit No.

Timing

Components of Care

Visit 1

Up to 12 weeks

Register the pregnancy, initial screening (blood pressure, hemoglobin, blood grouping), and tetanus vaccination.

Visit 2

16–20 weeks

Monitor weight, hemoglobin, and provide counseling on nutrition and lifestyle; ultrasound for fetal development.

Visit 3

24–28 weeks

Screening for anemia, blood pressure monitoring, offer iron and folic acid supplementation.

Visit 4

32–36 weeks

Focus on fetal monitoring (position and movements), tetanus vaccination if needed, and provide education on labor and delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is excluded from the composition of the fetal biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Contraction stress test

Explanation:

  • Contraction stress test is not a part of the fetal biophysical profile.
  • The contraction stress test assesses the response of the fetal heart rate to contractions induced by administering oxytocin or nipple stimulation. It is used to evaluate the fetal response to stress and to assess placental function.

 

Fetal movement (Option A) assesses the presence and quantity of fetal movements. It involves observing the fetus's body or limb movements within a specific time period.

Fetal breathing (Option B) evaluates the presence of rhythmic fetal breathing movements. It assesses the movement of the fetal diaphragm and helps determine fetal lung maturity.

The Non-Stress Test (NST) (Option C) measures the fetal heart rate in response to fetal movement. It assesses the reactivity and accelerations in the fetal heart rate, which indicates a healthy and responsive fetus.

questions.text: A woman, who is currently 38 weeks pregnant, visits the outpatient department for a regular checkup. She had previously given birth to healthy twins at full term, 4 years ago. What is her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) G2P1

Explanation:

  • G2P1 indicates that the woman has had two pregnancies (gravida 2) and one delivery (para 1). This option correctly accounts for the given history of a normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. Gravida refers to the total number of pregnancies a woman has had, including the current pregnancy. Para refers to the number of pregnancies that have reached 20 weeks or more, regardless of the outcome (whether the pregnancies resulted in live births, stillbirths, or abortions).

Incorrect Options:

G2P2 (Option A) implies that the woman has had two pregnancies (gravida 2) and two deliveries (para 2). However, the given history states that she had a normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago, which counts as one pregnancy (gravida 1) and one delivery (para 1). Therefore, this choice is incorrect.

G3P2 (Option C) would imply that the woman has had three pregnancies (gravida 3) and two deliveries (para 2). However, the given history only mentions one previous delivery, so this choice does not accurately represent the woman's history. Therefore, this choice is incorrect.

G3P1 (Option D) suggests that the woman has had three pregnancies (gravida 3) and one delivery (para 1). Again, this option overestimates the number of pregnancies the woman has had based on the given history. Thus, this choice is also incorrect.

questions.text: What is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 8

Explanation:

  • According to the World Health Organization (WHO), a minimum of 8 antenatal visits is recommended for a healthy pregnancy. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to achieve a positive pregnancy outcome.
 

WHO Recommendations

Indian Recommendations (National Guidelines)

under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)

Minimum Visits

8 visits

4 visits

questions.text: During her routine antenatal check-up, a 25-year-old woman's arterial blood gas analysis revealed an abnormality characterized by elevated pH and reduced carbon dioxide (CO2) levels in the blood. What type of arterial gas abnormality would likely be observed in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chronic respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

  • Respiratory alkalosis occurs when there is a decrease in CO2 levels in the blood due to hyperventilation, leading to an elevated pH. Chronic respiratory alkalosis indicates that this process has been ongoing for some time, allowing for partial renal compensation (reduction in bicarbonate).

ABG features in pregnancy:

  • pH: Slightly elevated (due to reduced CO2).
  • CO2: Decreased (due to hyperventilation from progesterone).
  • Bicarbonate: Slightly reduced (compensatory renal response).
  • ABG Pattern: Mild respiratory alkalosis with partial compensation (reduced bicarbonate).

 

During pregnancy, women often experience mild hyperventilation due to increased progesterone levels, leading to reduced CO2 and a slightly elevated pH. The body partially compensates over time, but the primary abnormality remains respiratory in nature.

Acute metabolic acidosis (Option A) is characterized by a decrease in blood pH due to an accumulation of acids (like lactic acid) or a loss of bicarbonate.

Acute metabolic alkalosis (Option B) is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to an excess of bicarbonate or a loss of hydrogen ions (e.g., from vomiting).

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings will be observed in a 19-year-old female patient presenting with weakness, amenorrhea, fatigue, and a history of being constantly worried about weight gain, accompanied by poor appetite and a BMI of 15.8?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyperthyroidism

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms, including weakness, amenorrhea, fatigue, poor appetite, and a low BMI (indicative of possible weight loss), suggest hyperthyroidism.
  • This condition occurs due to excessive thyroid hormone production, leading to increased metabolic rates and symptoms such as weight loss, fatigue, and amenorrhea.
  • The constant worry about weight gain may also indicate an underlying thyroid imbalance, as hyperthyroidism can cause disturbances in mood and appetite.

 

Hypocholesterolaemia (Option A) is not typically associated with hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is more likely to cause a reduction in cholesterol levels due to increased metabolism, but it is not a prominent laboratory finding in this case.

Hypersecretion of corticotropin-releasing hormone (Option C) is more related to conditions like Cushing's syndrome, which involves excess cortisol production. The symptoms described in this case do not align with those of Cushing's syndrome.

Hyperglycaemia (Option D) is not a typical characteristic of hyperthyroidism. In fact, the increased metabolism in hyperthyroidism may lead to more glucose utilization, which could potentially result in hypoglycemia rather than hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hegar's sign

Explanation:

Hegar's sign is elicited by bimanual examination in early pregnancy (around 6–8 weeks), revealing a softening of the lower uterine segment between the cervix and the uterine body. This softening allows the cervix and uterine body to feel like two separate structures.

  • Softening occurs due to hormonal effects (increased vascularity and edema from estrogen/progesterone).
  • Detected by gently pressing the cervix from below (per vaginam) and the uterine fundus from above (per abdomen).
  • A probable sign of pregnancy (not diagnostic).
  • Helps distinguish early pregnancy from other uterine enlargements.

Early Signs of Pregnancy

Description

Cause

Week of Pregnancy

Hegar's sign

Softening of the lower uterine segment

Increased vascularity and relaxation of the smooth muscle

6-8 weeks of gestation

Chadwick's sign

(Jacquemier’s sign) (Option A ruled out)

Bluish discoloration of the cervix and vagina

Increased vascularity in response to hormonal changes in pregnancy.

8th week

Goodell's sign (Option B ruled out)

Softening of the cervix

Increased vascularisation and edema.

6th week

Piskacek's sign (Option D ruled out)

Asymmetric enlargement of the uterus

Lateral implantation of fertilised ovum

-

Palmer's sign

Regular and rhythmic uterine contractions

Due to increased estrogen levels, and the physiological adaptations of the uterus preparing for labor

4-8 weeks

Osiander's sign

Increased pulsations felt through lateral fornices

Increased blood flow uterus by the uterine arteries

8th-12th week

questions.text: After an initial serum β-hCG test in a patient with suspected pregnancy, when should the repeat β-hCG level ideally be checked to assess viability or progression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 48 hours

Explanation: β-hCG levels are checked ideally after 48 hours.

In a viable intrauterine pregnancy, the serum β-hCG level should rise by at least ~66% over 48 hours in early gestation.

  • This doubling time is a key marker of normal trophoblastic function.
  • Slower rises can indicate ectopic pregnancy or failing pregnancy, while falling levels suggest miscarriage.
  • The lowest level of serum β-hCG at which a gestational sac is consistently visible using TVS (discriminatory zone) is ≥ 1,500 IU/L.So if the beta-hCG level is ≥ 1,500 and no intrauterine pregnancy is seen, an ectopic pregnancy is highly suspected.

questions.text: A woman presents for her first antenatal visit and reports that her LMP was approximately 2 months ago. Which ultrasound parameter is the most accurate for dating the pregnancy at this stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Crown-rump length

Explanation: The most accurate is crown–rump length (CRL) because between 7–13 weeks gestation, CRL is the most accurate parameter for dating a pregnancy.

  • At 2 months (~8 weeks), the embryo is clearly visible, and CRL gives a precise measurement from the top of the head to the bottom of the buttocks, unaffected by growth variations.

Dating accuracy by parameter:

  • <6–7 weeks → Mean gestational sac diameter
  • 7–13 weeks → Crown–rump length (most accurate overall)
  • 14–20 weeks → Biparietal diameter
  • Late pregnancy → Multiple parameters (BPD, HC, AC, FL)

Biparietal diameter (Option A): Most accurate from 14–20 weeks; not the best choice this early.

Mean gestational sac diameter (Option B): Used before the embryo is visible (<6–7 weeks); less accurate than CRL once the embryo is measurable.

Abdominal circumference (Option C): Used in the second and third trimesters to estimate fetal weight, not for early pregnancy dating.

questions.text: A woman comes to the clinic with breast tenderness, presence of linea nigra on her abdomen, and a bluish discoloration of the cervix. What is the most likely clinical interpretation of these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Probable pregnancy

Explanation: Probable pregnancy is the most appropriate answer. The described signs - breast changes, linea nigra, and bluish discoloration of the cervix (Chadwick’s sign) - are probable signs of pregnancy. These are objective changes noted on physical examination that strongly suggest pregnancy, but are not conclusive without further confirmation (e.g., ultrasound or fetal heart sounds).

Confirmed pregnancy (Option B): Requires positive signs such as fetal heart sounds (Doppler), fetal movements felt by examiner, or ultrasound visualization of the fetus. The given findings are not confirmatory.

Normal menstrual cycle (Option C): These pigmentation and vascular changes are not seen in a normal cycle.

Menopause (Option D): Menopause is associated with amenorrhea and low estrogen signs (atrophic changes), not hyperpigmentation or cervical vascularity.

questions.text: What contributes to the increase in blood volume during a woman’s term pregnancy?

choices.text: Increased fluid retention by the kidneys

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Both options A & B

Explanation:

Physiology of increased blood volume in pregnancy

  • The blood volume expands rapidly, reaching its maximum of 40–50% above the nonpregnant level at 30–34 weeks, ensuring an adequate supply of nutrients and oxygen to support the developing fetus and maternal physiological changes during pregnancy.

Role of aldosterone and estrogen:

  • The increase in blood volume is associated with enhanced sodium (Na) retention driven by hormonal changes like increased aldosterone levels during pregnancy.
  • There is an increased demand for blood flow to support the growing fetus and maternal tissues during pregnancy.
  • The increased aldosterone production promotes the reabsorption of sodium and water in the distal tubules and collecting ducts, enhances GFR, contributing to the expansion of blood volume.
  • Estrogen levels rise significantly during pregnancy.
  • First detectable at 9 weeks (0.05 ng/ml) and increases gradually to about 30 ng/ml at term.
  • Estrogen plays a role in upregulating the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS), further influencing sodium and water retention in the kidneys.

Aldosterone (Option C), as mentioned earlier, enhances sodium and water retention. However, with an increased production of ADH during pregnancy, plasma levels remain unchanged due to increased metabolic clearance by placental vasopressinase, limiting its impact on the increase in blood volume during pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the early sign of pregnancy on TVS?
questions.solution:
The gestational sac is the first visible structure on TVS, appearing at around 4.5 to 5 weeks of gestation.

 

Transvaginal sonography (TVS):

  • Establish gestational age and confirm pregnancy location.
  • More sensitive than Transabdominal sonography.
  • Structure identification:

 

Structure

Timing

Gestational sac (1st sonographic evidence of pregnancy)

4-5 weeks

Yolk sac (Option B)

5.5 weeks

Fetal pole and cardiac activity (Options C and D)

5-6 weeks
  • Intrauterine Pregnancy indicators:
    • Eccentric implantation of normal gestational sac in endometrium (pseudosac is seen in the midline).
    • Intradecidual sign: Anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim

Double decidual sign: Two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

questions.text: Primigravida at 39 weeks AOG, with good uterine contractions, normal vitals, and FHR at 150 bpm, shows a 6 cm dilated cervix (6 hours after the initiation of the contractions) and fetal head at -2 station with absent membranes. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Rupture of membranes and confirm cord prolapse

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Observe

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate a normal labor progression in a primigravida requiring observation only.

  • The cervical dilation of 6 cm after 6 hours of contractions represents an appropriate rate of dilation (approximately 1 cm/hour), which is within normal limits for a primigravida.
  • The fetal heart rate of 150 bpm is reassuring, and the presence of good uterine contractions indicates effective labor progress.
  • The fetal station at -2 with absent membranes suggests normal descent and spontaneous rupture of membranes, all of which are favorable signs in active labor.

 

Emergency C-section (Option A): No indications for emergency cesarean section as both maternal and fetal parameters are normal. There is no fetal distress or arrest of labor. Emergency C-section would be indicated for non-reassuring fetal status or other obstetric emergencies.

Start oxytocin (Option C): With good uterine contractions and normal labor progression, augmentation with oxytocin is not indicated. Unnecessary use of oxytocin could lead to uterine hyperstimulation and fetal compromise.

Rupture of membranes and confirm cord prolapse (Option D): The membranes are already noted to be absent, making this intervention inappropriate. Additionally, deliberately checking for cord prolapse without indication could introduce infection risk.

questions.text: Which Leopold's maneuver is done to assess the lie of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leopold's 1

Explanation:

  • Leopold's maneuver 1 is specifically used to determine the fetal lie through abdominal palpation.

Key Features of Leopold's 1:

  • Purpose: Determines fetal lie and presentation
  • Technique: Palpation of fundus
  • Assessment: Identifies which fetal part occupies the fundus
  • Outcome: Determines longitudinal versus transverse lie

Maneuver

Hand Position

Purpose

Findings

First (Fundal Grip)

Both hands on fundus facing patient

Determines fetal presentation and position

Identifies fetal parts (head or buttocks)

Head: Hard, round

Breech: Soft, irregular

Second (Lateral Grip)

Hands placed on sides of abdomen

Locate fetal back and limbs

Back: Smooth surface

Limbs: Small knob-like parts

Third (Deep Pelvic)

Thumb and fingers grasp above symphysis pubis

Identify presenting part

Determines if head is engaged

Head: Hard, round

Breech: Soft, irregular

Fourth (Pelvic Grip)

Facing patient's feet, fingers pressed downward

Assess engagement

Confirms cephalic prominence

Engaged: Fixed part

Not engaged: Mobile part

questions.text: A primigravida came to the emergency department at 1 pm with a 5 cm dilated cervix and at 4 pm with 6 cm dilation, next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Intervention to be done

Explanation:

  • Patient is in active stage of labor (cervix 5 cm dilated)
  • In 3 hours, cervical dilation increased only 1 cm, indicating poor progress, which requires management steps.
  • Normal rate of cervical dilation in active labor is 1 cm/hour and descent is 1cm/hour

Management Principles:

  • If there is poor contraction and poor progress of labor, oxytocin is administered
  • If there are good contractions and poor progress of labor, cesarean section is advised

 

Slow progress of labor (Option A): This represents a diagnosis rather than a management plan. Simply identifying slow progress without implementing appropriate interventions does not address the underlying problem and may lead to prolonged labor with associated risks.

Wait for complete dilation (Option B): Expectant management is inappropriate when labor progression falls below accepted standards. Prolonged labor increases risks of maternal exhaustion, fetal distress, and other complications. Active intervention is necessary to prevent adverse outcomes.

Induce labor (Option C): Induction of labor is contraindicated as the patient is already in the active phase. Using induction agents in active labor could lead to uterine hyperstimulation and fetal compromise. The appropriate intervention would be either augmentation with oxytocin if contractions are inadequate, or consideration of cesarean delivery if cephalopelvic disproportion is suspected.

questions.text: What is the ideal number of antenatal visits recommended during pregnancy according to Indian health care systems?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 13 visits

Explanation: The recommended or ideal number of antenatal visits according to Indian healthcare systems is at least 13 visits throughout pregnancy.

WHO Recommended Minimum ANC visits: 8

Govt. Of India Recommended Minimum ANC Visits: 4

Ideal number of visits: 13 or 14

1st Trimester: 1 visit. (within 12 weeks of gestation)

1st visit: <12 weeks

Upto 7 months: once every month

2nd Trimester: 2 visits. (weeks - 20 & 26)

2nd visit: 14-26 weeks

 

8th month: twice every month

3rd Trimester: 5 visits. (weeks - 30, 34, 36, 38 & 40)

3rd visit: 28-32 weeks

9th month: Once every week

 

4th visit: 36 weeks to term

 

6 visits (Option B), 8 visits (Option C), and 4 visits (Option D) are all inadequate according to the ideal recommendation of Indian health care guidelines, though they may represent minimum standards in different guidelines (WHO recommends 8, GOI recommends minimum 4).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician expressing her desire to become pregnant in the next few months. She is currently not taking any medications or supplements and wants to know what preventive measures she should take before conception. Which vitamin is given to prevent neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Folic acid

Explanation:

Deficiency of Folic Acid can lead to Neural Tube Defects (NTD).

Key Points About Folic Acid

  • Requirement: 400 mcg/day
  • If on anti-epileptics: Replacement dose - 4000 mcg/day (4 mg/day)
  • Neural Tube Defect (NTD) screening at 11-14 weeks: Only defects seen at this time on ultrasound (USG) are anencephaly and acrania

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) (Option A): While important for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function, thiamine does not prevent neural tube defects. Its deficiency is associated with different conditions like Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Vitamin B3 (Niacin) (Option B): Niacin is involved in DNA repair and metabolism but has no role in preventing neural tube defects. It serves different metabolic functions in the body.

Vitamin B12 (Option D): Although vitamin B12 is essential for neurological function and red blood cell formation, it does not directly prevent neural tube defects. It works synergistically with folate but is not the primary preventive agent for NTDs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G1P0 woman presents for routine prenatal ultrasound at 18 weeks gestation. The ultrasonographer notes scalloping of the frontal bones creating a lemon-like appearance of the fetal skull. Which of the following conditions is associated with both the "lemon sign" and "banana sign" on a prenatal ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A) Neural Tube Defects (NTD) - Spina Bifida

Explanation:

  • The "lemon sign" and "banana sign" is a specific ultrasound finding indicative of spina bifida, a type of neural tube defect
  • Lemon sign refers to scalloping of the frontal bones, which creates a lemon-like appearance of the fetal skull
  • This finding, along with other features like the "banana sign" which indicates a curved cerebellum, suggests spina bifida

 

 

Anencephaly (Option B): This condition presents with the characteristic "frog eyes" sign on ultrasound due to absent cerebral tissue above the orbits. Neither lemon nor banana signs are associated with this condition. Anencephaly is a more severe form of neural tube defect that is typically diagnosed earlier in pregnancy.

Down Syndrome (Option C): This chromosomal condition is associated with different ultrasound markers including increased nuchal fold thickness, absent nasal bone, and shortened femur length. The lemon and banana signs are not characteristic features of Down syndrome. Diagnosis typically requires genetic testing such as amniocentesis or cell-free DNA testing.

Brachycephaly (Option D): This cranial shape abnormality presents with a shortened anteroposterior diameter of the skull and increased biparietal diameter, creating a rounded appearance. It does not produce the lemon or banana signs. Brachycephaly may be isolated or associated with various syndromes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida has just delivered a healthy baby vaginally at 39 weeks gestation. The newborn has good muscle tone, is breathing spontaneously, and has normal skin color. The delivery team is preparing for umbilical cord clamping and discussing the optimal timing. What is the ideal time for umbilical cord clamping after birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C) Between 1-3 minutes after birth

Explanation:

Clamping the umbilical cord between 1-3 minutes after birth is considered the ideal time because:

  • It allows for significant transfer of blood from the placenta to the baby
  • Improves iron levels in the newborn
  • Supports better developmental outcomes
  • Enhances newborn health through improved blood volume
  • Reduces the risk of iron deficiency
  • Lower incidence of:
    • Necrotizing enterocolitis
    • Intraventricular hemorrhage

Immediately after birth (Option A) can prevent the baby from receiving additional blood from the placenta, potentially depriving the newborn of important nutrients and stem cells beneficial for early development.

Within 30 seconds of birth (Option B): While slightly better than immediate clamping, this timeframe still does not allow enough time for optimal blood transfer from the placenta, resulting in reduced iron stores.

More than 3 minutes after birth (Option D): While still beneficial, waiting longer than 3 minutes is generally unnecessary as most beneficial blood transfer occurs within the first 1-3 minutes, with no additional significant advantages.

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement?

choices.text: Gonads are bipotential at 8 weeks of gestational age
DHT is necessary for the development of external genitals
MIS inhibits the formation of Mullerian duct
Wolffian duct forms male internal genitalia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Gonads are bipotential at 8 weeks of gestational age

The gonads are bipotential only till 6th week post-fertilization. Before 7 weeks of embryonic development, embryos of male and female sex cannot be differentiated.

  • Gonads originate from the genital ridge, which develops in 4th-week post-fertilization.
  • This remains undifferentiated and can form the ovary or testis, called the bipotential stage. This stage remains till the 6th week post-fertilization.
  • During this time, the coelomic epithelium is formed from the genital ridge.
  • The epithelium proliferates and invaginates into the mesenchyme to form the primitive sex cords.

In males, the SRY gene on the Y chromosome triggers the development of testes, accompanied by the formation of Sertoli cells and Leydig cells. Leydig cells secrete testosterone, a hormone crucial for sexual differentiation.

Through the action of 5-alpha reductase, testosterone is converted into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent form. Testosterone guides the differentiation of the Wolffian duct for the internal male genitalia, while DHT is instrumental in the development of the male external genitalia (Option B).

Sertoli cells produce anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH), also known as Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS), which halts the development of the Müllerian system (Option C) comprising the uterus, fallopian tubes, and vagina.

Testosterone guides the differentiation of the Wolffian duct for the internal male genitalia (Option D), while DHT is instrumental in the development of the male external genitalia.

questions.text: Identify the CTG pattern?
questions.solution:
The given CTG image shows early deceleration.

Early decelerations are characterized by a gradual decrease and return of fetal heart rate (FHR) that mirrors uterine contractions. The onset, nadir (lowest point), and recovery of the deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and end of the contraction. This pattern is typically benign and results from fetal head compression, commonly observed during active labor.

Interpretation of CTG :

  • Baseline FHR: Average FHR between contractions (110-160 bpm). Abnormal ranges indicate fetal distress.
  • Baseline Variability: Fluctuations in baseline FHR reflect nervous system balance. Reduced variability may indicate hypoxia, acidosis, or other factors.
  • Accelerations: Transient FHR increases with fetal movement, indicating a healthy fetus with intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular function.
  • Decelerations: Transient FHR decreases below baseline.

Types of Decelerations:

Type

Characteristics

Cause

  

Early Decelerations

Gradual decline and recovery of FHR that coincide with the onset and recovery of the contraction. The nadir of the deceleration occurs ≥30 seconds after onset. The nadir of the deceleration occurs ≥30 seconds after onset.

Fetal head compression

Gradual decrease mirroring contractions.

 

Late Decelerations

Gradual decline in FHR that begins at or after the contraction’s peak and recovers after the contraction ends. The nadir occurs ≥30 seconds after onset.

Fetal hypoxia, uteroplacental insufficiency

Begin after contraction peak, uniform U-shaped.

Variable Decelerations

Abrupt FHR drop (≥15 bpm) with onset varying between contractions. Onset-to-nadir <30 sec, duration ≥15 sec but <2 min.

Umbilical cord compression

Abrupt, irregular, "V" or "W" shapes.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to the GYN OPD with a positive UPT test result. She already has twins by normal delivery. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) G2P1

In this case scenario,

  • G (gravida)- present pregnancy + twin pregnancy = 2
  • P (parity)- twin pregnancy =1

 

  • Hence, the obstetric score in this case is G2P1 as she has two total pregnancies and 1 delivery that completed 20 weeks of gestation.

The obstetric score includes:

Gravida

Denotes a pregnant state both present and past, irrespective of the period of gestation

Parity

Denotes a state of previous pregnancy beyond the period of viability(28 weeks)

Abortion

Number of pregnancies lost before 24 weeks

Living

Number of living children

Note: Twin pregnancy counts as one for both gravida and parity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presents at 36+6 weeks. The ultrasound shows the fetus in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no risk factors. Both her previous delivery were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - External cephalic version

  • In the given scenario, the pregnant woman presents at 36+6 weeks with a transverse lie and an external cephalic version could be the appropriate next step in management to attempt to reposition the fetus for a potential vaginal delivery.

Management of transverse lie

  • Antenatal management: If there are no contraindications, attempt an external cephalic version (ECV) beyond 35 weeks for the transverse lie.
  • If Version Fails or is contraindicated: Elective cesarean section is the preferred delivery method.
  • Management in labor: In early labour, try an external cephalic version (ECV) if appropriate or opt for cesarean section if ECV is unsuccessful. In late labour, ECV is usually impractical due to ruptured membranes, so cesarean section is preferred in such cases.
  • Internal version considerations: Only for specific cases like managing the second twin.

 

Cesarean section (Option A) is a surgical procedure in which the baby is delivered through an incision in the mother's abdomen and uterus. While a transverse lie is an indication of cesarean section, it is not the first-line management option in this scenario. If possible, non-invasive and conservative approaches are preferred before resorting to surgery.

Expectant management (Option C) involves closely monitoring the patient and waiting for spontaneous changes in the fetal position or the onset of labour. However, in the case of a transverse lie at term, expectant management is not recommended due to the increased risk of cord prolapse and potential complications during delivery.

Induction of labour (Option D): The fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, which means the baby is not in a favourable position for a safe vaginal delivery. Attempting induction could increase the risk of complications such as cord prolapse or obstruction.

questions.text: A woman presents to you at 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of feeling lightheadedness and dizziness when she lies on her back. She says she feels alright if she lies on her side or when she walks. What is the most likely reason behind this?

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IVC compression (IVC- Inferior Vena Cava)

  • The symptoms of shortness of breath due to lying on her back imply a decreased cardiac output. It usually occurs in pregnant women due to compression of the inferior vena cava and aorta by the gravid uterus when lying in the supine position and is called supine hypotensive syndrome.
  • It leads to reduced venous return, decreased cardiac output, and hypotension.
  • It causes nausea, dizziness and shortness of breath.
  • This condition is relieved by shifting to a left lateral position.

Increased intracranial pressure (Option A): The fact that the woman feels fine when lying on her side or walking suggests that it helps alleviate the pressure on the IVC and improves blood flow to the heart and brain. This position promotes better circulation and reduces the risk of increased intracranial pressure and associated symptoms. Although increased intracranial pressure can cause this condition, it is less likely than IVC compression.

While heavy meals (Option C) can cause postprandial hypotension (a drop in blood pressure after eating), the woman's symptoms are specifically associated with lying on her back, indicating a different underlying cause.

Excessive venous pooling at the feet (Option D), such as in cases of dependent oedema, is unlikely to cause lightheadedness and dizziness, specifically when lying on the back.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is correct in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Serum creatinine decrease

Explanation: Serum creatinine decreases during pregnancy.

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) During Pregnancy: (Option A)

  • Increases by 25% by the second week of pregnancy and by 50% in the first trimester.
  • Elevated GFR persists until term despite a decline in renal plasma flow in late pregnancy.

Serum Creatinine During Pregnancy:

  • Normal nonpregnant level: ~0.7 mg/dL.
  • Declines to ~0.5 mg/dL during pregnancy.
  • Values >0.9 mg/dL may indicate renal disease.

Platelet Count During Pregnancy:

  • Average platelet count decreases throughout pregnancy. (Option B & D)
  • Returns to nonpregnant levels within 4 to 12 weeks postpartum.
  • Platelet counts are lower in twin pregnancies.

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation?


	Goodell's sign
	Osiander's sign
	Internal ballottement
	Lightening
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:
At 8 weeks of gestation, Goodell's sign and Osiander's sign can be elicited.

 

Goodell's sign (Option 1): The softening of the cervix, noticeable as early as the 6th week of pregnancy, is a classic sign of pregnancy.

Osiander's sign (Option 2): Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity, often observed around 8 weeks of gestation.

 

Sign

Description

Time of Occurrence

Goodell's Sign (1)

Softening of the cervix

6th week

Ladin's Sign

Softening at the midpoint of the isthmus anteriorly

Around 6 weeks

Jacquemier's/Chadwick's Sign

Dark bluish-red coloration of the vaginal mucosa and cervix

6-8 weeks

Palmer's Sign

Regular & rhythmic uterine contractions

4-8 weeks

Von Braun-Fernwald's Sign

Irregular softening and enlargement of the uterine fundus

5-8 weeks

McDonald's Sign

Easy flexibility of the uterus on the cervix

7-8 weeks

Hegar's Sign

Firm cervix contrasts with the softer fundus, with a compressible, softened isthmus

6-10 weeks

Piskacek's Sign

One half of the uterus is firmer than the other half (lateral implantation)

6-12 weeks

Osiander's Sign (2)

Presence of a softening, compressible, and enlarging uterus, often felt with palpation

8th week

Placental Sign

Cyclic bleeding occurring up to 12 weeks of pregnancy

Up to 12 weeks

 

Internal Ballottement (3):

Palpation technique to detect fetal movement by bouncing the fetus away and then back.

Elicited between 16-28 weeks of gestation.

  • Before 16 weeks: Fetus too small.
  • After 28 weeks: Fetus too large.

Limitations:

  • Scanty liquor amnii (low amniotic fluid).
  • Transverse lie of fetus.

 

Lightening (4):

Relief of pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part into the pelvic cavity.

Felt around 38 weeks of gestation, primarily in primigravida (first-time pregnancies).

questions.text:
Consider the following actions under AMTSL (Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor). Arrange them in the correct order:


	Uterine massage
	Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 IU)
	Exclude the presence of another fetus
	Controlled cord traction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 3,2,4,1

 

Explanation:

The correct sequence in Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) is 3, 2, 4, 1, which is the recommended order to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

 

Steps Before Starting AMTSL:

  • Confirm delivery of the baby.
  • Exclude the presence of another fetus in the uterus.(Statement 3)
  • Assess fetal condition, position, and lie.
  • Prepare the uterotonic drug.
  • Check maternal vitals and overall condition.
  • Ready instruments for cord clamping.
  • Inform the mother about the procedure.
  • Check for signs of placental detachment.


 

1. Injecting Uterotonics

Inject uterotonic (e.g., Oxytocin 10 IU) within 1 minute of delivery of the baby or immediately after the delivery of the anterior shoulder. (Statement 2)
  • Most important step in AMTSL.
  • Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV infusion) is the preferred uterotonic.
  • Not recommended by WHO: carboprost.
  • Administer within 1-3 minutes of delivery.

2. Delayed Cord Clamping

Delay cord clamping for at least 1 minute after birth.
  • About 80 ml of additional blood goes to the fetus.
  • Helps prevent fetal anemia by allowing time for placental blood flow to transfer to the baby.

3. Delivery of Placenta by Controlled Cord Traction

Perform controlled cord traction using the modified Brandt-Andrews technique. (Statement 4)
  • Controlled cord traction should be done after administering uterotonics.
  • Technique: apply gentle downward traction to the cord while counter-traction on the uterine fundus facilitates placental delivery.

4. Intermittent Assessment of Uterine Tone

Assess uterine tone intermittently to ensure uterine contraction is maintained.
  • Done every 15 minutes for 2 hours post-delivery.
  • Only in settings where skilled birth attendants are available.
  • Uterus is pushed upwards and backward while cord traction is downward and forward.

5. Uterine Massage (Optional)

Perform uterine massage only if uterine atony is suspected or after placental delivery. (Statement 1)
  • Not recommended as a routine intervention to prevent PPH in women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics (Oxytocin).
  • Now an optional component of AMTSL in cases of uterine atony or PPH management.

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus?

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cry of baby in the womb

 

Explanation:

  • Vagitus uterinus is a Latin term that translates to "uterine cry" or "womb cry." It refers to the cry or sound made by a fetus while still inside the mother's womb, typically in the later stages of pregnancy.
  • This is a rare phenomenon where the fetus is capable of producing vocalizations.
  • In certain circumstances, these sounds can be detected during ultrasound examinations or heard by the mother, although this is not commonly observed.
  • Vagitus uterinus is a fetal vocalization and has no association with any infections or pathological conditions. (Options B, C and D ruled out)

questions.text: What can be said about this graph?

choices.text: The baseline shows that the fetus has tachycardia.
This is a uterine contraction graph.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) This is a non-stress test.

 

Explanation:

 

The given graph, showing only the tracing for the fetal heart rate (FHR), indicates a non-stress test (NST).

 

Non-Stress Test (NST):

  • It is a non-invasive test used to assess fetal well-being by monitoring the fetal heart rate and its response to fetal movements.
  • It is typically performed in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • The mother is placed in a semi-reclining position, and two belts are placed around her abdomen to measure the fetal heart rate and detect fetal movements.

 

Indications for NST:

  • Post-term pregnancy.
  • Decreased fetal movements.
  • High-risk pregnancies (e.g., hypertension, diabetes).
  • History of previous pregnancy complications.
  • Suspected intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

 

Primary parameters evaluated during an NST:

 

1. Baseline Fetal Heart Rate (FHR)

2. Beat-to-beat Variability:
  • Normal: 110-160 bpm
  • Bradycardia: less than 110 bpm.
  • Tachycardia: more than 160 bpm.
  • Fluctuations in the heart rate from one beat to the next.
  • Amplitude range of 6-25 bpm (considered normal).

3. Accelerations
  • Temporary increases in FHR above the baseline.
  • Reactive NST:
    • At least two accelerations in a 20-minute period.
    • Each acceleration should be 15 bpm above the baseline and last for at least 15 seconds (for fetuses older than 32 weeks).
  • Non-Reactive NST: Fewer than two accelerations in a 20-minute period.

4. Decelerations

Temporary drops in FHR below the baseline.

  • Early Decelerations: Usually benign, occurring with uterine contractions.
  • Variable Decelerations: Can indicate umbilical cord compression.
  • Late Decelerations: Concerning as they may indicate uteroplacental insufficiency.

5. Fetal Movements
  • The presence and frequency of fetal movements are monitored, as decreased movements can indicate distress.

Interpretation:
  • Reactive NST: Indicative of normal fetal oxygenation and autonomic function.
  • Non-Reactive NST may require further testing, such as a Biophysical Profile (BPP) or Contraction Stress Test (CST).

The baseline shows that the fetus has tachycardia (Option B): Tachycardia is defined as a baseline fetal heart rate above 160 beats per minute. The tracing in this graph shows a baseline fetal heart rate below 160 bpm, so tachycardia is not present.

 

The beat-to-beat variability is less/inadequate (Option C): Beat-to-beat variability refers to the fluctuations in the baseline fetal heart rate, excluding accelerations and decelerations. A variability of 6-25 beats/min is considered normal. This graph shows normal beat-to-beat variability, and thus, this option is incorrect.

 

This is a uterine contraction graph (Option D): This graph shows only fetal heart rate tracing and does not include any data on uterine contractions. A cardiotocogram (CTG), which includes both fetal heart rate and uterine contraction tracings, would be required for uterine contraction monitoring.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Daily fetal movement count

 

Explanation:
Daily fetal movement count is not a component of the biophysical profile (BPP).

 

Biophysical Profile (BPP)

 

Parameter

Normal Criteria

Breathing Movements

>1 episode lasting >30 seconds

Amniotic Fluid Volume

≥1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (Option A ruled out)

Fetal Tone

≥1 episode of active limb or trunk extension with return of flexion (e.g., opening and closing of the hand) (Option B ruled out)

Gross Body Movements

>3 discrete body/limb movements

Non-stress Test (NST)

Reactive pattern (Two accelerations of 15 seconds duration, 15 bpm, in 20 minutes) (Option D ruled out)

 

BPP Scoring and Interpretation

 

BPP Score

Interpretation

Management

10

Normal, non-asphyxiated fetus

No action required; Routine monitoring

8

Normal, non-asphyxiated fetus

Repeat test weekly or biweekly for high-risk pregnancies (e.g., diabetic, post-term)

6

Possible fetal asphyxia

Repeat testing; If score ≤6, consider delivery

4

Probable fetal asphyxia

Repeat test same day or deliver if AFV is abnormal or >36 weeks

0-2

Almost certain fetal asphyxia

Immediate delivery

 

BPP Score and Outcome:

 

  • A BPP score of <4 suggests a fetal pH of <7.2, which indicates fetal distress and potential acidemia.
  • A BPP score of 0 represents 100% fetal acidemia, indicating severe metabolic acidosis and a very high risk of stillbirth or perinatal mortality.


 

Modified Biophysical Profile
The modified biophysical profile (mBPP) includes only two components:

 

NST (Nonstress Test)

Fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements

AFI (Amniotic Fluid Index)

Measurement of amniotic fluid volume

 

The mBPP is primarily used for routine surveillance, particularly in high-risk pregnancies, and takes less time (around 10 minutes).

 

Interpretation of MBPP

 

Non-reactive NST or AFI <5

Non-reassuring (abnormal result)

Reactive NST and AFI ≥ 5

Reassuring (normal result)
